abstract.p: Venus Williams advances to quarterfinals of Pilot Pen Tennis Tournament in New Haven, defeating Yelena Likhovtseva 6-3,7-5; Monica Seles advances by defeating Kristina Brandi 6-2,6-3 (S)

block.p: For the fourth straight time, Venus Williams defeated Yelena Likhovtseva by 6-3, 7-5, tonight to advance to the Pilot Pen quarterfinals.
This afternoon at the Connecticut Tennis Center, second-seeded Monica Seles also reached the quarterfinals by defeating Kristina Brandi, 6-2, 6-3.
For the fourth straight time, Venus Williams defeated Yelena Likhovtseva by 6-3, 7-5, tonight to advance to the Pilot Pen quarterfinals.
This afternoon at the Connecticut Tennis Center, second-seeded Monica Seles also reached the quarterfinals by defeating Kristina Brandi, 6-2, 6-3.

Likhovtseva is ranked 23rd and beat Venus's sister Serena in the Round of 16 at this year's Australian Open. But the 24-year-old Russian has not been able to beat Venus Williams. Recently, no one has.
Because of tendinitis in both wrists, Williams missed the first five months of competition this year. But she has won her last three events, including Wimbledon.

But the top-seeded Williams was in far from top form tonight. After breaking the Russian's service five times in a row en route to opening up a 3-0 lead in the second set, Williams had to fight off four set points in the 10th game, which went to nine deuces before she held serve.
''I don't think I was as intense as I should have been,'' Williams said.
Seles's 98 mile-an-hour ace closed out her victory, but it was the zip on her pinpoint groundstrokes that kept Brandi on her heels.
''I missed some shots because of my timing,'' the 26-year-old Seles said. ''And my arm felt very good.''
That would be her left arm, which she strained several weeks ago while favoring blisters on her left hand.
